Entries.default: The bound man casts a wary stare down at you, his arms tightening weakly beneath their restraints.
Nodding to you in recognition, Tamau sighs and rolls his head to the side, waiting for you to speak up.
"What can I do for you?"
"You stole the last of the tribe's koīki?"
"I had some questions."
"Farewell."

"If only my brain and my belly had coordinated, I say I would have tried sooner." 

He glances longingly toward the hut north of the ranga's.
Tamau turns his face to one side, refusing to acknowledge you.
Stretching to crack his spine, Tamau favors you with a tired, disinterested glance.
"I found the missing koīki fruit."
He blinks at you, narrowing his eyes.
"Then maybe you ask someone with both feet on the ground."

"Pekeho hates me because I insult his puny catches of fish. All he does is weigh down his boat.

"For this he accuses me."
"What's your side of the story?"
"Pekeho says I was skulking by the drying hut north of the ranga's home. Ekera, this is so."
"I would have taken the koīki, but it was already gone."
"I had other questions."
"I need to conserve my strength."
"You'll want to speak with this knife-wielding baboon. Mukūmu!" Tamau jerks his head to gesture the warrior over.

"You look at me for what? To watch me shrivel up in the sun?"

It may be a trick of the light, but the man's emaciated scowl does appear shriveled.
"I hope you do not come for thanks? My gratitude pouch is as empty as my belly, I say."
"Lots around here who would answer better than me. I never learned much except how to find food."
"Tell me about yourself."
"Don't know how long a man could last out here like that."
"I don't like this, Watcher. Is there nothing we can do to help?"
"I say that a bound man is usually a more welcoming sight than this."
"What say?" Tamau gives you a strained smile.
"Can you think of anyone else who might have taken it?"

"It is said the Roparu share one empty stomach. Blame any of them, I say."

He grimaces down at his lean frame.
"The tribe dries me out like jerky because I am hated - not because I am a koīki thief."
"I have seen better days than this." He grimaces up at you.
"I labor for the tribe, but our ranga saves the best of everything for his warriors."
"For what does a warrior need with a full stomach when we are not at war?" Tamau shakes his head and scowls.
"Who is the hagfish now, Mukūmu?"
"So you ARE just a thief."
"I stole no koīki." Tamau's upper lip curls back.
"And you are not my ranga. Unless you come to put a spear through Mukūmu's eye, keep your distance I say."
"You're not even a little thankful?"
"Just checking in on you."
[Slap him.]
"For what, because I am no longer accused? I say you set a low bar."
He snorts derisively and focuses his attention elsewhere.
"You could have done that from afar, I say."

He cries out in shock as his head whips to the side. Raising a hand to his cheek, he searches the faces of other villagers who witnessed the exchange. 

None of the onlookers pay any mind beyond a passing glance.
"Ekera... I hope you enjoy sinking to my level, outsider."
"Did they abuse the Roparu in your tribe? Disgusting, I say."
He wipes a line of spit from the side of his mouth and shakes it to the ground.

"Fitting that one with so little sympathy for others finds none when he feels wronged."

She gives a wry smile.
"Damn, you beat me to it." Maia folds her arms and grins.
"Filthy traitor!" He hisses at Maia.
"No one in the tribe spoke for me when I was bound to a pole, lady knight." He nurses his cheek, wincing.
